issues.title: Github Action for IETF I-D
issues.author: OR13
issues.body:
Eventually we probably want to move away from markdown2rfc to a proper github actions scripts.

See bbs+ repo for examples.

issues.title: Abstract must address all registered key and signatures
issues.author: OR13
issues.body:
Basing our abstract off of https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8812

We should simply acknowledge the registrations by name, and avoid any other langauge.

comments.author: mprorock
comments.body: this should now be in, but we need a stronger abstract re need for PQC, need for interop, etc

comments.author: OR13
comments.body: @mprorock I think we actually don't want to get real verbose here... I think that the security considerations section is probably a better place to address interop... or another section of the spec...

issues.title: Do we want to rename this repo?
issues.author: brownoxford
issues.body: It looks like we have settled on `post-quantum-jose` for the draft name, should we modify the repo name to match?

comments.author: OR13
comments.body: i suggest keeping the name as is... and leaving the door open for COSE.

comments.author: mprorock
comments.body:
COSE is definitely also applicable

We should also be considering this as a potential home as the WG shakes out https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/saag/sS9Qok2fh9lktcsQp0axEJnh_pk/

see also:
https://github.com/rdanyliw/ietf-pq-maintenance/blob/main/pqm-charter.md

comments.author: OR13
comments.body: I suggest we drop jose from all the file names.

comments.author: brownoxford
comments.body:
> 

Were you thinking we should go back to `post-quantum-signatures`, or something different?

comments.author: OR13
comments.body: the repo name is fine... I would build a single `draft-post-quantum-signatures` spec in it for now.

comments.author: brownoxford
comments.body: Sounds good - will put in a PR when other outstanding PRs for the draft body have been resolved.

issues.title: Flag draft as an update to RFC7518 (JWA).
issues.author: mprorock

comments.author: OR13
comments.body: hmm... I think you mean RFC7515, which we already cite.... which in turn refers to RFC7518... not sure how we should treat them both.

issues.title: Update Editors, Authors and Contributors
issues.author: mprorock
issues.body:
- [ ] spec has no more than 5 editors
- [ ] spec editors contact information has been confirmed
- [ ] additional contributors added to the acknowledgement section

@OR13 can you break apart editors on the top line from the additional contributors per some feedback from IETF folks

comments.author: OR13
comments.body:
See [guidelines](https://www.ietf.org/standards/ids/guidelines/).

Ideally we do some analysis of the spec and come up with a data driven way to assign these roles, then adjust based on feedback that was given verbally and other factors.

issues.title: Do we want one spec or several?
issues.author: mprorock
issues.body:
Open question for discussion:
1) Single spec covering PQC signatures and each scheme as a section (this is totally fine for incubation independent of where things shake out)
2) One spec per scheme
3) one spec for broad PQC usage with JOSE and then one spec per scheme that reference that spec

comments.author: OR13
comments.body:
For sure to start, we should assume 1 spec... and have it cover key and signature serializations in JSON and CBOR.

I don't think we get a big benefit for splitting CBOR and JSON up, and there is precedent for doing them at the same time... see https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8812.

I also don't think we get a huge benefit from splitting by crypto system... although I think that could be argued against.

In general, we are defining serializations for lattice and hash based schemes... splitting along those lines would make sense... IF each list was very long and needed a lot of special treatment... but since we are really only looking at serializations I don't think that will be the case... we are not here to define crypto, only serializations of defined crypto.

comments.author: brownoxford
comments.body: I did a quick test and, should we decide to go that route, the build framework will work on any and all `draft*.md` files in the repo.

issues.title: Update spec development instructions
issues.author: OR13
issues.body:
The readme instructions should assist a contributor in setting up, building and previewing local spec changes.

The instructions should work in all operating systems, or list the only supported OS.

comments.author: OR13
comments.body:
Currently getting this error in macOS:

```
❯ make
cat draft-post-quantum-jose.md  | mmark | lib/add-note.py | xml2rfc -q -s 'Setting consensus="true" for IETF STD document' --rfc-base-url https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/ --id-base-url https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/ --cache=/Users/orie/.cache/xml2rfc --v2v3 /dev/stdin -o /dev/stdout >draft-post-quantum-jose.xml
bash: mmark: command not found
Error: Unable to parse the XML document: /dev/stdin
make: *** [draft-post-quantum-jose.xml] Error 1
make: *** Deleting file `draft-post-quantum-jose.xml'
```

comments.author: brownoxford
OR13
brownoxford
comments.body: Per our offline conversation, I will modify `README.md` to include basic instructions for building `txt` and `html` versions of the draft spec for local review by installing the latest `mmark` and `xml2rfc` on Linux and OSX and also by running the relevant docker commands.

issues.title: Build Error: Incomplete or empty [seriesInfo] in title block, resulting XML will fail to parse
issues.author: brownoxford
issues.body: It looks like `mmark` issues an error if `stream` is missing from the `[seriesInfo]` block.

issues.title: Embedded SVGs are problematic
issues.author: brownoxford
issues.body:
Embedded SVGs cause the build process to produce many errors, and omit the math entirely from TXT versions of the draft:

```
3.3.1.  Generate

   (Artwork only available as svg: spec/key-gen.svg)

                                  Figure 1
```

Can we refactor this into text format? I took a look at some other specs, e.g., [bbs+](https://identity.foundation/bbs-signature/draft-bbs-signatures.html), and they seem to use text for the math (doesn't look great though).

issues.title: References to CRYSTALS-Dilithium cause "Too Wide" warnings
issues.author: brownoxford
issues.body:
These references are currently included as untyped code blocks which `mmark` converts into `<artwork>` elements.  Currently, this is resulting in a number of warnings regarding elements and sections being "too wide" by `xml2rfc`:

```
/Users/cabernet/Documents/src/github.com/brownoxford/post-quantum-signatures.git/draft-post-quantum-jose.xml(256): Warning: Artwork too wide, reducing indentation from 3 to 2
/Users/cabernet/Documents/src/github.com/brownoxford/post-quantum-signatures.git/draft-post-quantum-jose.xml(287): Warning: Artwork too wide, reducing indentation from 3 to 0
/Users/cabernet/Documents/src/github.com/brownoxford/post-quantum-signatures.git/draft-post-quantum-jose.xml(284): Warning: Section too wide, reducing indentation from 0 to 0
/Users/cabernet/Documents/src/github.com/brownoxford/post-quantum-signatures.git/draft-post-quantum-jose.xml(178): Warning: Section too wide, reducing indentation from 0 to 0
/Users/cabernet/Documents/src/github.com/brownoxford/post-quantum-signatures.git/draft-post-quantum-jose.xml(175): Warning: Section too wide, reducing indentation from 0 to 0
/Users/cabernet/Documents/src/github.com/brownoxford/post-quantum-signatures.git/draft-post-quantum-jose.xml(66): Warning: Section too wide, reducing indentation from 0 to 0
/Users/cabernet/Documents/src/github.com/brownoxford/post-quantum-signatures.git/draft-post-quantum-jose.xml(39): Warning: Middle too wide, reducing indentation from 0 to 0
```

This can be easily solved by converting these references to blockquotes instead of code blocks, which actually seems more appropriate in this case.

issues.title: JSON code samples contain lines longer than 69 chars
issues.author: brownoxford
issues.body: `xml2rfc` complains about lines longer than 69 characters. This can be fixed by wrapping lines as described in [RFC 8792](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8792).

addresses https://github.com/mesur-io/post-quantum-signatures/issues/4
